entity.entity_description: The physical body of the dead person intended to be preserved and protected within the pyramid or tomb in ancient Egyptian burial practices.

entity._class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture

class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture

entity.entity_description: Ancient Egyptian burial and embalming process of preserving a corpse to prevent decay and prepare it for the afterlife, involving body preservation through organ removal, desiccation, and wrapping.
entity.resolution_context: Both refer to the same Egyptian body-preservation burial practice in this context, with 'body preservation' described specifically as the act within mummification rather than a separate concept.
entity._class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture

class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture

entity.entity_description: Soft organs inside the body that were removed during mummification.
entity.resolution_context: This process typically involved removing the internal organs and drying out the body with salt before wrapping it in linen bandages. The removal and separate treatment of internal organs were characteristic steps within Egyptian mummification practices aimed at long-term body preservation.
entity._class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture

class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture

entity.entity_description: Use of salt to dry out a corpse as part of mummification.
entity.resolution_context: This process typically involved removing the internal organs and drying out the body with salt before wrapping it in linen bandages. The use of salt to desiccate the body was a crucial stage in preventing decay and achieving effective preservation for the afterlife.
entity._class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture

class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture

entity.entity_description: Strips of linen cloth used to wrap the mummified body.
entity.resolution_context: This process typically involved removing the internal organs and drying out the body with salt before wrapping it in linen bandages. The linen bandages formed the outer covering of the mummy, enclosing the preserved body for burial in the tomb or burial chamber.
entity._class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture

class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture

entity.entity_description: The ancient Egyptian religious conception of the afterlife, encompassing the post-death realm, the journey of the soul, associated deities, and the rituals and practices intended to ensure safe passage and eternal life.
entity.resolution_context: Both mentions are explicitly described as referring to the same ancient Egyptian concept of the afterlife, differing only in label granularity, so they should be unified into one belief-system entity covering the realm and its associated doctrines.
